Title: Canon Powershot S10 IS
Cons: None
Pros: Features, lens, zoom, etc.
Comments: I have used a Sony Cybershot for several years but struggled until I sold it with photos coming out blurry.  This is my second Canon and I wonder why I ever left.  The day it arrived we left on family vacation for the Outer Bnaks in NC.  I took photos every day and we would look at them at night as a family.  I deleted very few photos and I love this camera.  The 20x zoom is awesome and with up to 10 megapixel, you can use different combinations to get some great photos.  Try this camera.  You will like it!

Title: slr to "point and shoot"
Cons: only bad thing i have to say is when using a phone memory card with the adapter you get a mem card error every once and a while but if you take it out and make sure everything is snugly put together it works great after a reformat for good measure.
Pros: excellent point shoot camera with both an insane zoom lens and a great supermacro mode for those extremely close shots. feels good in the hand and with the viewfinder and screen you cant go wrong when you have the choice between the two.
Comments: typically i use a canon digital rebel xti, and i know thats not exactly the best of the best as far as slr cameras are concerned but its pretty darn good. well what im getting at is this "point-shoot" camera is pretty much the equivalent to the xti but with the ease of use of your common point shoot camera. the zoom is excellent almost surpassing the need for a telephoto lens like the one i use on my xti, and with supermacro mode you can see the individual strands that make up the strings that make up a pair of denim jeans so your pretty squared away there.

Title: Excellent Canon Camera
Cons: Would have liked to see a better lens cap on it. Very fussy to put the lens cap back on.
Pros:
Great image quality
Excellent movie quality
Battery life/power management is good. Took approximately 600 photos with the camera before it gave me the 'replace batteries' warning.
Comments: Overall, an excellent camera.

Title: Meets and Exceeds all Expectations
Cons:
- Heavy. 
- Video cable crackles audio when feeding to my TV, although that could be my own TV's fault.
- At higher zooms, your aperture selection is limited.
- "Auto" mode gives me only GOOD photos, need to go manual to get the best.
- No lens cap strap included (but at least it comes with a cap!)
Pros:
- Heavy.
- Well planned out buttons and intuitive controls, once you read the manual.
- Flip screen so I don't smudge up the screen with my face when I use the viewfinder.
- Large body so there is actually someplace for my thumb to go!
- Immense Zoom (see cons).
- Every feature you could need in a hobby camera.
- Image stabilization provides good hand held shots down to 1/30 shutter speed in good light.
- AA batteries are available nearly everywhere. This camera does not eat batteries.
- FLIP UP FLASH (see other thoughts)
Comments:
Other reviews have extensively covered the technical dominance of this camera, so I'll focus on my user experience.

As a casual photographer, I didn't need a DSLR, but I wanted a well thought out, effective, full manual mode. This camera also features neat little extras which make taking photos an involved experience.

The camera's body is large and has lots of space to position your hands, with well placed buttons and controls. Too many DSLR-like cameras today are just a lens with a huge screen on the back. 

My favorite feature about this camera is its manually raised flash. Too often on other cameras, I would set up my shot just the way I liked it, push the shutter release, and the flash would spring up and wash out my shot. If I don't want the flash, I would rather have it physically DOWN, UNABLE TO FIRE, than scroll though a menu or push multiple buttons to disable the flash. 

Instead, if the camera needs the flash, It simply notifies you after focusing, and you make the

Title: Not a point and shoot
Cons: F-stops are limited with this big lens. Image stabilization is excellent. A bit of fringing at it's limits but I'm not a DD (Darkroom Diva) or a PP (pixel Peeper). I shoot memories not perfection or art. Besides, if the pic is a great composition it should stand in black and white. As for lens cap tether, I bought a Cap Keeper II for a couple bucks. I would like to know how to mount filters on this thing. Slippery? Yup but I use this thing called a neck strap. As for batteries, try and get a lithium battery charged when your out in the boonies or in a foreign country. AA's are easy to find and carry. I use the reformulated NiMH that holds their charge. They work well and last.
Pros: Innumerable features. Canon does have good glass. Major plus is the silent, functional, zoom when doing video. Stereo mics work well and , I believe, zooms with the lens at least in some of the action videos I've shot it seems as if they have. I have video taken from across the lake, at three quarter full zoom, of some friends Ice surfing and the mikes pickup the sounds of the skates very well and it's between 1/8th and a 1/4 mile away. Shot without a tripod and the image stabilization worked incredibly well. Camera has a hot shoe (rare) and with a good flash it should take flash pictures much quicker than with the built in flash. Uses AA batteries.(a good thing.) I've done digital since the first Casios and have owned and have had die multiple cameras since. Some were great and some were so so. This one is a champ. It's full auto setting works well and full manual and and in between settings are well thought out as are the buttons their function and their placements.
Comments: This camera is small and very light compared to the SLR's with a lens or group of lenses that have a similar capability. Have you seen those? They're huge. And SLR's don't do video, especially with optical zoom intact. I have pocket cameras as well but they don't compare. And to make up for this camera's short comings would take a good SLR back and several lenses and would cost thousands which I don't have to spend for fun. Some of my friends do, and have the high dollar outfits. They've used my camera and have considered this camera as a backup, the shlubs.

Cons:
* Every camera with a compact sensor has issues with dynamic range.  I'm not docking an egg for this because it's expected in this class of camera, but just pointing it out.  You won't get SLR performance from this.

* The lens cap doesn't attach very well and has no cord to attach it to the camera, so it would be easy to lose.

* No RAW mode, but you can add that yourself with the open source CHDK firmware expansion (google it...)
Pros:
* Excellent set of features
* Nice build quality
* Uses AA batteries!  MUCH nicer than proprietary batts.  Use NiMH's, and you can bum a set of AA's off someone in a pinch.  No extra charger to keep track of.  Easy to carry spare sets, and they're far cheaper too.
* Good optics, wide range zoom.
* Works great with DigiKam under Ubuntu Linux (9.04).  I highly recommend this package.
* Feels like a miniature SLR.
* Allows total manual control over A, S, etc.
Comments: If you're really super serious you probably want to look at an SLR instead, but for more hobby and casual use, this is a great camera and takes excellent pictures.  Just no matter what camera you get, stay away from the proprietary batteries :)

Title: Great camera
Cons: No memory supplied, no way to attach filters, very poor zoom
Pros: Flip screen, hotshoe, AA batteries, 20X zoom, very well built, macro, comfortable to use
Comments: Since the majority of pictures most of us take require a flash it seems that Canon would have put a little more into the built in flash - My reason for only 4 eggs. The camera does have a hotshoe so the problem is one that can be corrected with a little extra cash. Otherwise I would consider this camera to be nearly the perfect mid-priced point and shoot digital camera

Title: WOW!!!
Cons: None.
Pros:
Just amazed
Great build quality
Photos look perfect
Pretty good low light performance
Fast
Hot shoe
Stero sound is very good
Great image stabalization!!!
Looks very good
Feels very good in the hand
AA batteries
Size is not to big or small (just right)
Comments: Movies look fantastic if there is plenty of light. Built in flash is just ok, not a pro or con. I would buy this again in a heart beat.

Title: great - all I expected
Cons: Lousy built in flash - it is not up to the quality of the rest of the camera. Flash photos appear washed out and overexposed close up, poor quality at a distance.
Pros: great features and versatile.   Overall fast shooting time for a camera in this price range. AA batteries.  Hotshoe for adding a decent flash.
Comments: Easily the best camera I have seen for the price.

Title: Thrilled
Cons:
Built in flash is on the weak side
Shots in low light are tricky
Pros:
Picture clarity
Shot delay (very fast from finger pushing to actual picture)
Easy of use (though there are many functions, it was quite easy to master the basics and not terribly difficult to move into some of the more intricate ones)
Zoom lens
Face recognition

I have video taken from across the lake, at three quarter full zoom, of some friends Ice surfing and the mikes pickup the sounds of the skates very well and it's between 1/8th and a 1/4 mile away. Shot without a tripod and the image stabilization worked incredibly well. Camera has a hot shoe (rare) and with a good flash it should take flash pictures much quicker than with the built in flash. Uses AA batteries.(a good thing.) I've done digital since the first Casios and have owned and have had die multiple cameras since. Some were great and some were so so. This one is a champ. It's full auto setting works well and full manual and and in between settings are well thought out as are the buttons their function and their placements.
Comments: This camera is small and very light compared to the SLR's with a lens or group of lenses that have a similar capability. Have you seen those? They're huge. And SLR's don't do video, especially with optical zoom intact. I have pocket cameras as well but they don't compare. And to make up for this camera's short comings would take a good SLR back and several lenses and would cost thousands which I don't have to spend for fun. Some of my friends do, and have the high dollar outfits. They've used my camera and have considered this camera as a backup, the shlubs.

Cons:
* Every camera with a compact sensor has issues with dynamic range.  I'm not docking an egg for this because it's expected in this class of camera, but just pointing it out.  You won't get SLR performance from this.

* The lens cap doesn't attach very well and has no cord to attach it to the camera, so it would be easy to lose.

* No RAW mode, but you can add that yourself with the open source CHDK firmware expansion (google it...)
Pros:
* Excellent set of features
* Nice build quality
* Uses AA batteries!  MUCH nicer than proprietary batts.  Use NiMH's, and you can bum a set of AA's off someone in a pinch.  No extra charger to keep track of.  Easy to carry spare sets, and they're far cheaper too.
* Good optics, wide range zoom.
* Works great with DigiKam under Ubuntu Linux (9.04).  I highly recommend this package.
* Feels like a miniature SLR.
* Allows total manual control over A, S, etc.
Comments: If you're really super serious you probably want to look at an SLR instead, but for more hobby and casual use, this is a great camera and takes excellent pictures.  Just no matter what camera you get, stay away from the proprietary batteries :)

Title: Great camera
Cons: No memory supplied, no way to attach filters, very poor zoom
Pros: Flip screen, hotshoe, AA batteries, 20X zoom, very well built, macro, comfortable to use
Comments: Since the majority of pictures most of us take require a flash it seems that Canon would have put a little more into the built in flash - My reason for only 4 eggs. The camera does have a hotshoe so the problem is one that can be corrected with a little extra cash. Otherwise I would consider this camera to be nearly the perfect mid-priced point and shoot digital camera

Title: WOW!!!
Cons: None.
Pros:
Just amazed
Great build quality
Photos look perfect
Pretty good low light performance
Fast
Hot shoe
Stero sound is very good
Great image stabalization!!!
Looks very good
Feels very good in the hand
AA batteries
Size is not to big or small (just right)
Comments: Movies look fantastic if there is plenty of light. Built in flash is just ok, not a pro or con. I would buy this again in a heart beat.

Title: great - all I expected
Cons: Lousy built in flash - it is not up to the quality of the rest of the camera. Flash photos appear washed out and overexposed close up, poor quality at a distance.
Pros: great features and versatile.   Overall fast shooting time for a camera in this price range. AA batteries.  Hotshoe for adding a decent flash.
Comments: Easily the best camera I have seen for the price.

Title: Thrilled
Cons:
Built in flash is on the weak side
Shots in low light are tricky
Pros:
Picture clarity
Shot delay (very fast from finger pushing to actual picture)
Easy of use (though there are many functions, it was quite easy to master the basics and not terribly difficult to move into some of the more intricate ones)
Zoom lens
Face recognition

Title: Canon Powershot S10 IS
Cons: None
Pros: Features, lens, zoom, etc.
Comments: I have used a Sony Cybershot for several years but struggled until I sold it with photos coming out blurry.  This is my second Canon and I wonder why I ever left.  The day it arrived we left on family vacation for the Outer Bnaks in NC.  I took photos every day and we would look at them at night as a family.  I deleted very few photos and I love this camera.  The 20x zoom is awesome and with up to 10 megapixel, you can use different combinations to get some great photos.  Try this camera.  You will like it!

Title: slr to "point and shoot"
Cons: only bad thing i have to say is when using a phone memory card with the adapter you get a mem card error every once and a while but if you take it out and make sure everything is snugly put together it works great after a reformat for good measure.
Pros: excellent point shoot camera with both an insane zoom lens and a great supermacro mode for those extremely close shots. feels good in the hand and with the viewfinder and screen you cant go wrong when you have the choice between the two.
Comments: typically i use a canon digital rebel xti, and i know thats not exactly the best of the best as far as slr cameras are concerned but its pretty darn good. well what im getting at is this "point-shoot" camera is pretty much the equivalent to the xti but with the ease of use of your common point shoot camera. the zoom is excellent almost surpassing the need for a telephoto lens like the one i use on my xti, and with supermacro mode you can see the individual strands that make up the strings that make up a pair of denim jeans so your pretty squared away there.

Title: Excellent Canon Camera
Cons: Would have liked to see a better lens cap on it. Very fussy to put the lens cap back on.
Pros:
Great image quality
Excellent movie quality
Battery life/power management is good. Took approximately 600 photos with the camera before it gave me the 'replace batteries' warning.
Comments: Overall, an excellent camera.

Title: Meets and Exceeds all Expectations
Cons:
- Heavy. 
- Video cable crackles audio when feeding to my TV, although that could be my own TV's fault.
- At higher zooms, your aperture selection is limited.
- "Auto" mode gives me only GOOD photos, need to go manual to get the best.
- No lens cap strap included (but at least it comes with a cap!)
Pros:
- Heavy.
- Well planned out buttons and intuitive controls, once you read the manual.
- Flip screen so I don't smudge up the screen with my face when I use the viewfinder.
- Large body so there is actually someplace for my thumb to go!
- Immense Zoom (see cons).
- Every feature you could need in a hobby camera.
- Image stabilization provides good hand held shots down to 1/30 shutter speed in good light.
- AA batteries are available nearly everywhere. This camera does not eat batteries.
- FLIP UP FLASH (see other thoughts)
Comments:
Other reviews have extensively covered the technical dominance of this camera, so I'll focus on my user experience.

As a casual photographer, I didn't need a DSLR, but I wanted a well thought out, effective, full manual mode. This camera also features neat little extras which make taking photos an involved experience.

The camera's body is large and has lots of space to position your hands, with well placed buttons and controls. Too many DSLR-like cameras today are just a lens with a huge screen on the back. 

My favorite feature about this camera is its manually raised flash. Too often on other cameras, I would set up my shot just the way I liked it, push the shutter release, and the flash would spring up and wash out my shot. If I don't want the flash, I would rather have it physically DOWN, UNABLE TO FIRE, than scroll though a menu or push multiple buttons to disable the flash. 

Instead, if the camera needs the flash, It simply notifies you after focusing, and you make the

The day it arrived we left on family vacation for the Outer Bnaks in NC.  I took photos every day and we would look at them at night as a family.  I deleted very few photos and I love this camera.  The 20x zoom is awesome and with up to 10 megapixel, you can use different combinations to get some great photos.  Try this camera.  You will like it!

Title: slr to "point and shoot"
Cons: only bad thing i have to say is when using a phone memory card with the adapter you get a mem card error every once and a while but if you take it out and make sure everything is snugly put together it works great after a reformat for good measure.
Pros: excellent point shoot camera with both an insane zoom lens and a great supermacro mode for those extremely close shots. feels good in the hand and with the viewfinder and screen you cant go wrong when you have the choice between the two.
Comments: typically i use a canon digital rebel xti, and i know thats not exactly the best of the best as far as slr cameras are concerned but its pretty darn good. well what im getting at is this "point-shoot" camera is pretty much the equivalent to the xti but with the ease of use of your common point shoot camera. the zoom is excellent almost surpassing the need for a telephoto lens like the one i use on my xti, and with supermacro mode you can see the individual strands that make up the strings that make up a pair of denim jeans so your pretty squared away there.

Title: Excellent Canon Camera
Cons: Would have liked to see a better lens cap on it. Very fussy to put the lens cap back on.
Pros:
Great image quality
Excellent movie quality
Battery life/power management is good. Took approximately 600 photos with the camera before it gave me the 'replace batteries' warning.
Comments: Overall, an excellent camera.

Title: Meets and Exceeds all Expectations
Cons:
- Heavy. 
- Video cable crackles audio when feeding to my TV, although that could be my own TV's fault.
- At higher zooms, your aperture selection is limited.
- "Auto" mode gives me only GOOD photos, need to go manual to get the best.
- No lens cap strap included (but at least it comes with a cap!)
Pros:
- Heavy.
- Well planned out buttons and intuitive controls, once you read the manual.
- Flip screen so I don't smudge up the screen with my face when I use the viewfinder.
- Large body so there is actually someplace for my thumb to go!
- Immense Zoom (see cons).
- Every feature you could need in a hobby camera.
- Image stabilization provides good hand held shots down to 1/30 shutter speed in good light.
- AA batteries are available nearly everywhere. This camera does not eat batteries.
- FLIP UP FLASH (see other thoughts)
Comments:
Other reviews have extensively covered the technical dominance of this camera, so I'll focus on my user experience.

As a casual photographer, I didn't need a DSLR, but I wanted a well thought out, effective, full manual mode. This camera also features neat little extras which make taking photos an involved experience.

The camera's body is large and has lots of space to position your hands, with well placed buttons and controls. Too many DSLR-like cameras today are just a lens with a huge screen on the back. 

My favorite feature about this camera is its manually raised flash. Too often on other cameras, I would set up my shot just the way I liked it, push the shutter release, and the flash would spring up and wash out my shot. If I don't want the flash, I would rather have it physically DOWN, UNABLE TO FIRE, than scroll though a menu or push multiple buttons to disable the flash. 

Instead, if the camera needs the flash, It simply notifies you after focusing, and you make the

Title: Not a point and shoot
Cons: F-stops are limited with this big lens. Image stabilization is excellent. A bit of fringing at it's limits but I'm not a DD (Darkroom Diva) or a PP (pixel Peeper). I shoot memories not perfection or art. Besides, if the pic is a great composition it should stand in black and white. As for lens cap tether, I bought a Cap Keeper II for a couple bucks. I would like to know how to mount filters on this thing. Slippery? Yup but I use this thing called a neck strap. As for batteries, try and get a lithium battery charged when your out in the boonies or in a foreign country. AA's are easy to find and carry. I use the reformulated NiMH that holds their charge. They work well and last.
Pros: Innumerable features. Canon does have good glass. Major plus is the silent, functional, zoom when doing video. Stereo mics work well and , I believe, zooms with the lens at least in some of the action videos I've shot it seems as if they have. I have video taken from across the lake, at three quarter full zoom, of some friends Ice surfing and the mikes pickup the sounds of the skates very well and it's between 1/8th and a 1/4 mile away. Shot without a tripod and the image stabilization worked incredibly well. Camera has a hot shoe (rare) and with a good flash it should take flash pictures much quicker than with the built in flash. Uses AA batteries.(a good thing.) I've done digital since the first Casios and have owned and have had die multiple cameras since. Some were great and some were so so. This one is a champ. It's full auto setting works well and full manual and and in between settings are well thought out as are the buttons their function and their placements.
Comments: This camera is small and very light compared to the SLR's with a lens or group of lenses that have a similar capability. Have you seen those? They're huge. And SLR's don't do video, especially with optical zoom intact. I have pocket cameras as well but they don't compare. And to make up for this camera's short comings would take a good SLR back and several lenses and would cost thousands which I don't have to spend for fun. Some of my friends do, and have the high dollar outfits. They've used my camera and have considered this camera as a backup, the shlubs.

Cons:
* Every camera with a compact sensor has issues with dynamic range.  I'm not docking an egg for this because it's expected in this class of camera, but just pointing it out.  You won't get SLR performance from this.

* The lens cap doesn't attach very well and has no cord to attach it to the camera, so it would be easy to lose.

* No RAW mode, but you can add that yourself with the open source CHDK firmware expansion (google it...)
Pros:
* Excellent set of features
* Nice build quality
* Uses AA batteries!  MUCH nicer than proprietary batts.  Use NiMH's, and you can bum a set of AA's off someone in a pinch.  No extra charger to keep track of.  Easy to carry spare sets, and they're far cheaper too.
* Good optics, wide range zoom.
* Works great with DigiKam under Ubuntu Linux (9.04).  I highly recommend this package.
* Feels like a miniature SLR.
* Allows total manual control over A, S, etc.
Comments: If you're really super serious you probably want to look at an SLR instead, but for more hobby and casual use, this is a great camera and takes excellent pictures.  Just no matter what camera you get, stay away from the proprietary batteries :)

Title: Great camera
Cons: No memory supplied, no way to attach filters, very poor zoom
Pros: Flip screen, hotshoe, AA batteries, 20X zoom, very well built, macro, comfortable to use
Comments: Since the majority of pictures most of us take require a flash it seems that Canon would have put a little more into the built in flash - My reason for only 4 eggs. The camera does have a hotshoe so the problem is one that can be corrected with a little extra cash. Otherwise I would consider this camera to be nearly the perfect mid-priced point and shoot digital camera

Title: WOW!!!
Cons: None.
Pros:
Just amazed
Great build quality
Photos look perfect
Pretty good low light performance
Fast
Hot shoe
Stero sound is very good
Great image stabalization!!!
Looks very good
Feels very good in the hand
AA batteries
Size is not to big or small (just right)
Comments: Movies look fantastic if there is plenty of light. Built in flash is just ok, not a pro or con. I would buy this again in a heart beat.

Title: great - all I expected
Cons: Lousy built in flash - it is not up to the quality of the rest of the camera. Flash photos appear washed out and overexposed close up, poor quality at a distance.
Pros: great features and versatile.   Overall fast shooting time for a camera in this price range. AA batteries.  Hotshoe for adding a decent flash.
Comments: Easily the best camera I have seen for the price.

Title: Thrilled
Cons:
Built in flash is on the weak side
Shots in low light are tricky
Pros:
Picture clarity
Shot delay (very fast from finger pushing to actual picture)
Easy of use (though there are many functions, it was quite easy to master the basics and not terribly difficult to move into some of the more intricate ones)
Zoom lens
Face recognition

I have video taken from across the lake, at three quarter full zoom, of some friends Ice surfing and the mikes pickup the sounds of the skates very well and it's between 1/8th and a 1/4 mile away. Shot without a tripod and the image stabilization worked incredibly well. Camera has a hot shoe (rare) and with a good flash it should take flash pictures much quicker than with the built in flash. Uses AA batteries.(a good thing.) I've done digital since the first Casios and have owned and have had die multiple cameras since. Some were great and some were so so. This one is a champ. It's full auto setting works well and full manual and and in between settings are well thought out as are the buttons their function and their placements.
Comments: This camera is small and very light compared to the SLR's with a lens or group of lenses that have a similar capability. Have you seen those? They're huge. And SLR's don't do video, especially with optical zoom intact. I have pocket cameras as well but they don't compare. And to make up for this camera's short comings would take a good SLR back and several lenses and would cost thousands which I don't have to spend for fun. Some of my friends do, and have the high dollar outfits. They've used my camera and have considered this camera as a backup, the shlubs.

Cons:
* Every camera with a compact sensor has issues with dynamic range.  I'm not docking an egg for this because it's expected in this class of camera, but just pointing it out.  You won't get SLR performance from this.

* The lens cap doesn't attach very well and has no cord to attach it to the camera, so it would be easy to lose.

* No RAW mode, but you can add that yourself with the open source CHDK firmware expansion (google it...)
Pros:
* Excellent set of features
* Nice build quality
* Uses AA batteries!  MUCH nicer than proprietary batts.  Use NiMH's, and you can bum a set of AA's off someone in a pinch.  No extra charger to keep track of.  Easy to carry spare sets, and they're far cheaper too.
* Good optics, wide range zoom.
* Works great with DigiKam under Ubuntu Linux (9.04).  I highly recommend this package.
* Feels like a miniature SLR.
* Allows total manual control over A, S, etc.
Comments: If you're really super serious you probably want to look at an SLR instead, but for more hobby and casual use, this is a great camera and takes excellent pictures.  Just no matter what camera you get, stay away from the proprietary batteries :)

Title: Great camera
Cons: No memory supplied, no way to attach filters, very poor zoom
Pros: Flip screen, hotshoe, AA batteries, 20X zoom, very well built, macro, comfortable to use
Comments: Since the majority of pictures most of us take require a flash it seems that Canon would have put a little more into the built in flash - My reason for only 4 eggs. The camera does have a hotshoe so the problem is one that can be corrected with a little extra cash. Otherwise I would consider this camera to be nearly the perfect mid-priced point and shoot digital camera

Title: WOW!!!
Cons: None.
Pros:
Just amazed
Great build quality
Photos look perfect
Pretty good low light performance
Fast
Hot shoe

Looks very good

AA batteries

Comments: Movies look fantastic if there is plenty of light. Built in flash is just ok, not a pro or con. I would buy this again in a heart beat.

Title: great - all I expected
Cons: Lousy built in flash - it is not up to the quality of the rest of the camera. Flash photos appear washed out and overexposed close up, poor quality at a distance.
Pros: great features and versatile.   Overall fast shooting time for a camera in this price range. AA batteries.  Hotshoe for adding a decent flash.
Comments: Easily the best camera I have seen for the price.

Title: Thrilled
